isis.stitle: 7.3 Liter Diesel Engine Service (1991) - VALVE TRAIN: CAMSHAFT, HYDRAULIC VALVE LIFTERS AND PUSH RODS - HYDRAULIC VALVE LIFTER ROLLER TYPE

svcproc.title: OPERATION
svcproc.para: Oil from oil gallery, is supplied to the lifter through a hole in the side of the lifter body which indexes with a groove and hole in the lifter plunger. Oil is then metered past the oil metering valve in the lifter, through the push-rods to the rocker arms.

When the lifter begins to roll up the cam lobe, the check valve is held against its seat in the plunger by the check valve spring which traps the oil in the base of the lifter body below the plunger. The plunger and lifter body then raise as a unit, pushing up the push-rod to open the valve. The force of the valve spring which is exerted on the plunger through the rocker arm and push-rod causes a slight amount of leakage between the plunger and lifter body. This "leak-down" allows a slow escape of trapped oil in the base of the lifter body. As the lifter rides down the other side of the cam lobe and reaches the base circle or "valve closed" position, the plunger spring quickly moves the plunger back (up) to its original position. This movement causes the check valve to open against the check valve spring and oil from which the plunger is drawn into the base of the lifter. This restores the lifter to zero lash ( Figure 4.2
).

note.para: Valve lifters and push rods should be kept in order so they can be re-installed in their original position. Good oil quality and following the recommended oil drain intervals are the key to long valve train life.
